object-07.text: We see wooden objects every day, from our house, to our school or office, or even on streets. These woods are being used in different forms. Have you wondered what these wood species are? How can we identify these wood species?

object-08.text:
Let us take a closer look and appreciate wood identification through this learning object entitled:

Wood Identification: Importance, Methods and Principles

object-14.text:
Objectives:

At the end of this learning object, the viewer should be able to:

1) recognize the importance of wood identification

2) describe the methods that can be used in wood identification

3) understand the principles involved in wood identification

object-15.text:
Wood Identification:

Importance, Methods and Principles

object-17.text: Our topic for today is about wood identification, its importance, methods and the principles involved in identifying woods.

object-18.text:
Wood identification is the establishment of the

 identity of a wood sample as being similar to or

identical with an already known wood species.

object-21.text:
Now, let me call your classmate assigned to report why identifying the species of wood is important.

Sue, could you tell us WHY IS WOOD IDENTIFICATION IMPORTANT?

object-23.text: I have found out that identification is important in various ways. First, it is important to know the identity of the wood species before processing it.

object-24.text: Great, Sue! Wood identification serves as a basis for proper utilization and conversion. We should know the identity of the wood so we will have an idea of its properties that are suitable for a particular use. Can you tell us another one?

object-25.text:
WHY IS WOOD IDENTIFICATION IMPORTANT?

1) it serves as a basis for proper utilization and conversion

object-27.text: 2) It serves as a basis for revenue collection

object-28.text: It is also important because it can serve as a basis for revenue collection.

object-29.text: Correct! Officers who are assigned in the collection of forest charges can correctly impose the respective taxes for the harvested logs.

object-30.text: How about if you are canvassing materials for your house construction? Can you select from the following choices the situation when skill in wood identification is beneficial to you?

object-31.text: You got it right! Another importance of wood identification is in the aspect of buying and selling lumber or wooden furniture. Buying and selling of incorrectly identified lumbers or furniture, be it intentionally or unintentionally meant by the seller or buyer can be prevented.

object-32.text: Ooopps, you picked the wrong answer. Come on, try again!

object-33.text: Now, back to you, Sue. Look at the slide and tell us when wood identification is beneficial to plant taxonomists.

object-34.text: When the tree is devoid of leaves, flowers and fruits, we can look into its wood to know its identity.

object-35.text: Correct, Sue! And lastly, it is crucial to know the identity of the unknown species if we are going to study it. Once we know the species, we will know its properties and we will have an idea on which aspect it should be studied further.

object-36.text:
Now that you know the importance of wood identification, let us look into the methods of identifying these wood species.

The first thing that we can do is to consult people with expertise in this field.

object-37.text: We can also compare the unknown sample with what is available in some wood identification handbooks.

object-38.text: It aids in checking frauds in buying lumbers

object-39.text: It helps in assisting plant taxonomists

object-40.text: It aids in research in wood science and technology

object-42.text: We can also compare the unknown sample with what is available in some wood identification references.

object-43.text: Wood library or technically xylarium is also a place to go to identify unknown samples, by comparing it with authentic samples stored in the xylarium.

object-44.text: Wood library or technically xylarium is also a place to go to identify unknown samples, by comparing it with authentic samples stored in the xylarium.

object-45.text: Wood identification using computer-operated devices or applications are available nowadays such as Xylotron and chemistry-based identification like near-infrared spectroscopy.

object-46.text: Wood identification using computer-operated devices or applications are available nowadays such as Xylotron and chemistry-based identification like near-infrared spectroscopy.

object-47.text:
Lastly, there are two types of keys that are still relevant in wood identification.

Can you pick from the list the two types of keys that are useful in wood identification?

object-48.text:
Lastly, there are two types of keys that are still relevant in wood identification.

Can you pick from the laret the two types of keys that are useful in wood identification?

object-49.text: Dichotomous keys use two contrasting statements, and its numbering is always like this: number of species to be identified less one (n-1 principle).

object-51.text: Card-sorting keys are boards with punched and solid edges. Written at the center of a card is a wood species name, and listed at the outer part are all the features that can observed in examining a wood. When a certain feature is present in the wood, it has a hole adjacent to it. However, if the feature is not present in the species, there will be no punch near the said feature.

object-53.text: Now that you know the different methods of wood identification, let us discuss the principles involved in wood identification.

object-54.text:
In identifying wood, the usual procedure is to approach it first from the gross to anatomical features - that is, from the visible characteristics wherein little or no magnification are needed, to features that can be observed only at high magnifications using microscope.

Using more characteristics, a more reliable identification can be made. It must be emphasized that a number of features taken together can give a more accurate identification.

Let’s discuss wood’s gross features that are of value in identification.

object-56.text: The gross features of wood is the sum of all physical and structural features of wood that are of value in wood identification. The physical features of wood are all the features of the wood that can be perceived by our senses. These are color, luster, odor, taste, grain, texture, weight and hardness.

object-58.text: The structural features are wood features based on their cellular makeup which are visible to the naked eye or with the aid of a hand lens. This group includes characteristics of the pores, parenchyma, wood rays, ducts and included phloem.

object-59.text: Let’s take a look first on the physical features of the wood. These features are observed without an aid of any magnification and are said to be subjective features, in the sense that different individuals may have different interpretations of these features.

object-60.text: Color in wood differs due mainly to extractives. It varies between and within species of wood. Many factors affect this feature, such as age, decay and weathering of wood. Color interpretation may also be subjective due to differences in individual interpretation of shades of color.

object-61.text: Luster is the ability of wood to reflect light. A wood may be classified as either lustrous or dull. This is also related to the amount of extractives present in the wood.

object-62.text: Some woods, especially when fresh, possess a distinct odor. Some woods smell like old leather and fresh beans. Some have irritating or agreeable odor. Some woods also have a distinct taste.

object-63.text:
Do you think odor is relevant in wood utilization?

YES OR NO?

object-64.text: You are Correct! Odor affects the utilization of wood. Due to its distinct odor, some are utilized as ointments, medicines, and cigar boxes.

object-65.text: Grain is the arrangement of cells in wood. It can be classified as straight or cross (curly, wavy, spiral, diagonal or interlocked). Grain varies within species or in the same piece of wood. Some of the methods in determining grain direction are splitting a veneer, dropping an ink on the wood surface and tracing the grain direction using a pointed object.

object-66.text: Texture is the size and the proportional amount of cells in the wood as seen in the cross section. The texture of a wood can be classified as coarse, fine, and very fine. For softwood species, the tangential diameter of the tracheids is the basis.

object-67.text: Wood hardness is determined by cutting a portion of wood with knife/cutter or by applying pressure on the wood with the fingernail. Wood can be classified as hard, moderately hard and soft. The more difficult it is to cut a portion or indent your nails the harder is the wood.

object-68.text: Weight is the last physical feature that can be observed in woods. Wood species are classified as heavy or light.

object-69.text: Can you tell which among the choices affect/s the weight of wood?

object-70.text: Structural features are more reliable bases for identification than the physical features. Cell distribution patterns and arrangements of vessels or pores, parenchyma, wood rays, and ducts belong to this category.

object-71.text: Pore is the cross section of a vessel element. It is only present in hardwood species. It can be described according to its arrangement, shape, size, occlusions and topography.

object-77.text:
Next structural feature is PARENCHYMA. These are short-thin-walled elements concerned primarily with storage and to a lesser extent in the distribution of carbohydrates.

It can be classified into apotracheal, paratracheal and boundary parenchyma cells.

object-81.text: Another structural feature is wood ray. Wood rays are ribbon-shaped strand of tissues extending in a radial direction across the grain. Ray width is important in wood identification. It can be described as broad or narrow.

object-82.text:
Presence of oil or resin ducts in wood is also helpful in identifying woods. These are longitudinally and/or horizontally oriented openings that are surrounded by cells secreting resinous, oily or gummy substance. These may occur as a normal characteristic feature or may arise due to injury.

It may be arranged in diffuse manner or in concentric manner. Ducts may also be empty or filled.

object-83.text: Completing the line-up of structural features of wood is the presence of included phloem in some wood. This refers to the presence of phloem (bark) in the xylem (wood).

object-84.text: Can you bring the arrow to point the included phloem in this wood sample?

object-101.text:
GROSS FEATURES = PHYSICAL + STRUCTURAL FEATURES



PHYSICAL FEATURES:

Color

Luster

Odor and Taste

Grain

Texture

Weight

Hardness

object-102.text:
STRUCTURAL FEATURES:

Pores

Parenchyma

Wood rays

Ducts

Included phloem

object-117.text:
PORES:

ARRANGEMENT

OCCLUSIONS

SHAPE

TOPOGRAPHY

SIZE

options.c: it aids in checking frauds in buying lumbers

options.b: chemical components in wood like extractives affect its weight
options.c: types of cells in wood affect its weight

object-184.question: Which of these are the two types of keys that are useful in wood identification?

object-231.text: That completes our discussion of physical features. The other set of features is the STRUCTURAL FEATURES.
